Description: Wooden ointment-spoon in the form of a bouquet of lotus-flowers. The buds are of inlaid pink-stained ivory, the leaves are painted green. The swivel-lid is attached by an ivory peg.
Curator's comments: Published: P. Kozloff, B. Bryan, and M. Berman, Egypt's Dazzling Sun, Cleveland 1992, pp. 359-360 [85] = Le Pharaon-Soleil, Paris 1993, pp. 317-318 [85]. Art and Afterlife in Ancient Egypt, Japan 1999-2000, [38]. For such fine 'cosmetic spoons', typically found in tombs though examples have been found in temples, see Egypt’s Golden Age (exhibition catalogue, Boston, 1982): 207-15.
